text.p: These are the headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
THE GLOBE AND MAIL:
- Socialists win in France: Left coalition will need Communists in order to form government.
- Leader will face daunting task: Lionel Jospin makes grey a primary color.
- Bailey confirms his title genuine: Johnson pulls up with injured leg.
- Manning's trusty sidekick shucks Eastern label: Friends, foes alike believe Rick Anderson has contributed to success of Reform's campaign.
- Tiananmen deaths far from forgotten: Thousands join in Hong Kong march.
- Voters show immunity to election fever: It's nearly time to go to the polls, and they're still uncertain. Those who did decide, decided to go golfing.
REPORT ON BUSINESS:
- Housing demand fuels boom: Starts to climb more than 20 percent, CMHC says; massive Toronto development in the works.
- Chrysler revamp ready to roll: Redesign of the flagship LH line from the wheels up was done in record time.
- Balaclava bows out of bid for BC Sugar: Pattison in wings with C$266 million.
- Union members aim for Reform: Propelled by feelings of powerlessness, workers are shunning the NDP's social-equality policies.
- New competition upsets grocery industry cart.
THE FINANCIAL POST:
- Bre-X faces one big lawsuit: Canadians too could push for damages south of border.
- Intel warning triggers high-tech panic.
- Return of star system for fund managers.
- In post-election Ottawa governing will be fun again.
((Paul Simao, Reuters Toronto Bureau (416) 941-8104))
